results.title: Coronation ceremony
results.creator_credit: Hindle Marriott Edgar, Central Office of Information and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: A film about the significance of the coronation ceremony. The opening sequences show, through old prints, pictures and tapestries, the history of the coronation ritual, and its gradual development to its present form. The film then gives, by means of black and white drawings, an artist’s impression of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II. Music composed by John Gardner and performed by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by John Hollingsworth. Story by Dermot Morrah, spoken by Leo Genn. Original drawings by James Gardiner and R. Jeffryes.

results.title: The Coronation
results.brief_description: Covers the main features of the 1953 coronation ceremony. Shows Queen Elizabeth travelling to Westminster Abbey in the State Coach; the service inside the Abbey; the actual crowning; and the Duke of Edinburgh’s declaration of allegiance; the procession back to Buckingham Palace; the appearance of the Royal Family on the Palace balcony. Includes short footage of Sir Robert Menzies at Westminster Abbey. Presented by Gordon Craig, commentary by Leslie Mitchell, script by Cecil Burge, edited by Gerald Sanger.

results.title: Coronary counter attack
results.brief_description: Outlines heart disease risk factors, and argues that aerobic exercise will reduce these risks. Gives guidelines for such selected activities as jogging, swimming, bicycling, walking, rope jumping and cross-country skiing. Featuring Dr Kenneth H. Cooper.

results.title: Cornish Valley
results.creator_credit: Great Britain. Ministry of Information and Verity Films
results.brief_description: A study of family life on farms in the Coombe Valley near the border of north Cornwall and Devon, an area fairly typical of the south-west peninsula of England, with open, wind-swept uplands, deep sheltered valleys, steep slopes and small fields.

results.title: The Cornish engine: a chapter in the history of steam power
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Philip Armitage and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Cornish Engine is the name given to the pumping engine built during the 19th century for removing water from the tin and china clay mines of Cornwall. The fame of the Cornish Engine spread through the world but its end was sealed by the invention of more efficient types of engines in the latter part of the 19th century.

results.title: Cornet at night
results.creator_credit: Stanley Jackson, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Tells a haunting story of boyhood on a prairie homestead. The boy, sent to town to find a strong hired hand, returns with a cornet player creating a tense atmosphere at supper. Later while milking, the farmer listens to the cornet, and understands that the boy’s need for music is as great as his own need for adequate help in the fields. The cornet player does not stay, but the echo of his music continues through the years. Based on a story by Sinclair Ross. (Awards: New York)

results.title: Coral kingdom
results.creator_credit: Noel Monkman and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The fish and corals of the Great Barrier Reef. Photographed underwater, the film shows many different shell fish and corals; box fish, king schnapper, seaworm, jellyfish, anemones and other sea creatures.

results.title: Copper plumbing
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Productions
results.brief_description: The development and use of prefabricated copper plumbing in Australia. The advantages of seamless copper tubing, enabling workshop assembly of plumbing units; how copper plumbing can be concealed in walls; how architect, builder and plumber can plan ahead together; how these techniques have been used in a number of Australian public buildings, offices, blocks of flats, and small homes.

results.title: Copper kaleidoscope
results.creator_credit: Herbert E. Meyer, Heinrich Fueter and Condor Films
results.brief_description: The seemingly unlimited use of copper and copper alloys through five thousand years of history has established this metal as one of the most valuable possessions for the human population. The film shows the digging of the ore, smelting, ingots, rolling, shaping, polishing and finally the many things made from copper today.
